choices.text: Annual new case detection rate per lac
Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability

questions.text: A public health official is evaluating the effectiveness of a health system in emphasizing early detection of leprosy in a community setting. Which of the following metrics would be most indicative of the system's commitment to early identification?" [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability

 

  • The proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade 2 disability is useful in determining whether the health system is giving importance to identifying leprosy in the community.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment completion rate: This measures the effectiveness of treatment adherence and success but does not directly reflect the system's ability to detect cases early.

 

Option B. Annual new case detection rate per lac: While it shows the number of new cases detected, it doesn't indicate how early these cases are being detected.

 

Option C. Treatment initiation rate: This measures how quickly diagnosed patients begin treatment but does not indicate how early the cases are being detected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability is a key indicator of the effectiveness of a health system in detecting leprosy early.
  • Lower proportions suggest better early detection efforts

choices.text: Get consent from mother for P/V

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to you with her mother, reporting abdominal discomfort and is found to be 12 weeks pregnant based on a positive urine pregnancy test. As a medical professional, what would be your initial course of action? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Inform Police

 

Explanation

 

In many jurisdictions, pregnancy in a minor may be considered evidence of statutory rape or sexual abuse, hence, informing the police is crucial for legal proceedings and safeguarding the minor.

 

Other Option

 

Option A. Start examining: Although a medical examination is necessary, it must be conducted with proper legal and parental consent, especially considering the age and the situation's sensitivity.

 

Option C. Preserve clothing: This could be necessary in a case where forensic evidence needs to be gathered, especially if there was recent assault. However, this would follow legal reporting.

 

Option D. Take consent from mother: Consent is crucial, especially for minors. However, it does not preclude the obligation to report statutory rape or sexual abuse to authorities.

 

Educational objective :

 

  • When dealing with potentially criminal situations involving minors, such as a young teenager's pregnancy, the first step is to ensure the situation is addressed legally and safely. 
  • Informing law enforcement and ensuring proper medical and legal procedures safeguard the minor's health and legal rights.

questions.text: A 38-year-old civil engineer is working on a construction project in an area recently affected by a devastating earthquake. To prevent future devastation, the local government has amended the building codes. These changes are aimed at ensuring structures in the area can better withstand seismic activity. The engineer reviews the changes to determine the best approach for the new construction project. This modification to the building codes is primarily an example of which phase of disaster management? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Disaster mitigation

 

  • The measures that are taken to prevent disasters from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies are part of disaster mitigation.
  • Mitigation involves measures designed either to prevent hazards from causing an emergency or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. In most cases mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system.

 

In Disaster Cycle, the steps involved are –

 

  1. Disaster Impact and Response: it involves search, rescue, first aid of the patients, triaging them according to the severity of their injuries and their likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention, tagging and identification of dead.
  2. Relief Phase or Disaster Containment by prompt assistance, epidemiological surveillance and disease control, vaccination, nutritional support.
  3. Rehabilitation involves restoration of the pre-disaster conditions. It takes into account assessment and restoration of water supply, food safety and supply, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, vector control.
  4. Disaster Mitigation involves measures aimed at reducing or preventing the hazards from causing any emergency or to dampen the effects of emergencies. It involves flood mitigation works, appropriate land-use planning, improved building codes and reduction or protection of vulnerable population and structures.
  5. Disaster Preparedness is a long-term programme of developmental activities which aims at strengthening the overall capacity and capability of the country to efficiently and effectively manage all the emergencies.  

 

   

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Disaster mitigation involves proactive measures such as improved building codes to reduce the impact of future disasters, aiming to lessen vulnerability and enhance resilience against potential hazards.

questions.text:
A pediatric resident is preparing a presentation on neonatal mortality in India. She finds a dataset from the verbal autopsy report (2010-2013) and wants to understand the hierarchy of factors contributing to neonatal deaths. Based on this data, how would you arrange these factors from the most significant contributor to the least? [INICET NOV 2021]

 

  1. Prematurity and low birth weight
  2. Birth injuries and birth asphyxia
  3. Congenital anomalies
  4. Sepsis
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 1>2>4>3

 

The most significant factors contributing to neonatal mortality are arranged as follows: Prematurity and low birth weight, followed by birth injuries and birth asphyxia, then sepsis, and finally congenital anomalies.

 

1. Prematurity and low birth weight: These are the leading causes of neonatal mortality due to complications associated with underdevelopment.

 

2. Birth injuries and birth asphyxia: These are significant contributors to neonatal deaths due to physical trauma and lack of oxygen during birth.

 

4. Sepsis: Infections are a major cause of death, particularly in the late neonatal period.

 

3. Congenital anomalies: These contribute to neonatal mortality but to a lesser extent compared to the other factors.

 

NNMR - Neonatal mortality rate is the number of neonatal deaths (deaths within completed 28 days after birth) per 1000 live births in that year

 

 

  • Early neonatal mortality (ENNM): Neonatal mortality in first week (1-7 days) of life
  • Late neonatal mortality (LNNM): Neonatal mortality in first to fourth week (8 – 28 days) of life
  • MCC of NNMR in India is preterm birth
    • MCC of ENNMR: Prematurity and congenital anomalies
    • MCC of LNNMR: Infections (diarrhea and tetanus)
  • As per 2022-23 data - India’s NNMR is 20 per 1000 live births
  • NNMR is directly related with birth weight and gestational age
  • NNMRboys >NNMRgirls 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of Neonatal mortality (0 – 4 weeks): 

 

  • Low birth weight and prematurity
  • Birth injury and difficult labour
  • Sepsis
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Hemolytic diseases of newborn
  • Conditions of placenta and cord
  • Diarrhoeal diseases
  • Acute respiratory infections
  • Tetanus

 

According to WHO, Preterm birth, intrapartum-related complications (birth asphyxia), infections and congenital defects are the leading causes of most neonatal deaths.

questions.text: In the 18th century, the East India Company engaged in the illicit trade of a specific substance with China, which played a significant role in the historical trade dynamics. What was the substance that the company smuggled into China during this time? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Opium

 

Explanation:

 

  • In 18th & 19th centuaries, EIC (East India Company) used to purchase Tea against Silver. 
  • By opium export, EIC were able to save their Silver and purchased tea against Opium.
  • Opium is derived from the poppy plant and has been used both medicinally and recreationally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cannabis: Marijuana, a psychoactive drug from the Cannabis plant, used both recreationally and medicinally around the world.

 

Option C. Magic Mushrooms: Refer to various types of mushrooms that contain psilocybin, a psychoactive compound. These have been used for centuries for their hallucinogenic effects.

 

Option D. Cocaine: Derived from the coca plant, cocaine is a powerful stimulant used primarily as a recreational drug.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In 18th century British East India company used to transport opium to China .

questions.text: What is the purpose of conducting a HEADSS evaluation? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Adolescents

 

Explanation

 

The HEADSS assessment is a structured psychosocial interview technique specifically designed to be used with adolescents. The purpose of conducting a HEADSS evaluation is to provide a comprehensive framework for obtaining a detailed history from adolescents. It covers several key areas, including:

 

  1. Home & Environment- Understanding the adolescent's living conditions, relationships with family members, and any issues at home.
  2. Education and Employment - Gathering information about the adolescent's school performance, educational aspirations, and employment status.
  3. Activities - Identifying the adolescent's involvement in extracurricular activities, hobbies, and how they spend their free time.
  4. Drugs - Assessing the use of drugs, alcohol, and tobacco, including experimentation and regular use.
  5. Sexuality - Discussing topics related to sexual activity, orientation, and practices to ensure safe and healthy sexual behaviors.
  6. Suicide/Depression - Screening for mood issues, depression, suicidal thoughts, or other mental health concerns.

 

Now Extended to become – HEEADSS

 

E – Eating and Exercise

 

S - Safety

 

Educational objective: 

 

The HEADSS assessment helps healthcare providers establish rapport with adolescent patients, identify risk factors, and discuss sensitive issues in a non-judgmental, confidential manner. This can lead to better health outcomes by addressing potential problems early.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a high risk group for HIV? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Long distance truck drivers (LDTD)

 

  • High-risk groups for HIV are populations that have both high risk and high prevalence of HIV. 
  • According to the National AIDS Control Program's epidemiological classification, high-risk groups include commercial sex workers, injecting drug users, men having sex with men, and transgenders. 
  • These groups have the highest risk of contracting and transmitting HIV due to their behaviors or circumstances.
  • Long distance truck drivers are classified as a bridge population, not a high-risk group. 
  • Bridge populations are those who contract HIV because they come in contact with the high-risk groups, and then potentially transmit it to the general population. 
  • Along with truck drivers, bridge populations include migrant laborers, partners of IDUs, clients of commercial sex workers, and populations in conflict areas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HIV Transmission Spectrum: High-Risk Groups vs Bridge Populations vs General Populations

questions.text: You are a public health researcher evaluating a new screening test for early detection of a specific disease in a community. Your team successfully conducted a pilot study in a small group. Before planning a large-scale implementation, you wish to ensure that the findings from your pilot study can be applied to larger, diverse groups of individuals outside your initial sample. This ability to extrapolate the findings in the broader population, i.e. the external validity of a screening test is related to which of the following options? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Generalizability

 

  • Generalizability refers to the extent to which the findings from a study or pilot test can be applied to a broader population.
  • It is a measure of the external validity of a study.
  • Ensuring that the results of a pilot study can be extrapolated to larger, diverse groups outside the initial sample is crucial for the success of large-scale implementations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stability: Refers to the consistency of test results over time, ensuring that repeated measurements yield the same results under unchanged conditions. While important, it does not address how findings apply to different populations.

 

Option B. Objectivity: Ensures that test results are unbiased and not influenced by the person administering the test. While critical for reliable results, it does not relate to applying findings to a broader population.

 

Option D. Repeatability: Refers to the consistency of the test results when repeated under identical conditions. This is crucial for reliability but does not address the applicability of the results to different populations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External validity of a screening test is related to generalizability.

 

Validity refers to what extent the test measures which it purports to measure (adequacy of measurement).

 

Types of Validity

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man has been diagnosed with tuberculosis. As part of his treatment plan, he is prescribed a combination of antitubercular drugs. While counseling him on the drug regimen, you explain the mechanisms of action of each drug. Which of the following combinations of statements accurately describe the mechanisms of some of the drugs used in treating tuberculosis? [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis
  2. Pyrazinamide is an enzyme inducer
  3. Rifampicin is used only in the treatment of tuberculosis
  4. Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 4

 

1. lsoniazid - INH is activated by catalase peroxidase (formed by Kat G) enzyme of mycobacteria. It acts by inhibiting the formation of mycolic acid.

 

4. Bedaquiline - Act by inhibiting ATP synthase enzyme, can result in QT prolongation

 

Other Options:

 

2. Pyrazinamide - Possess the best sterilizing activity (can kill slow growing bacteria) and makes the medium sterile. Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is not an enzyme inducer.

 

3. Rifampicin - Act by inhibiting RNA polymerase of mycobacteria by binding to its β-subunit. It thus inhibits transcription. Uses of Rifampicin are:

 

  • Tuberculosis
  • Leprosy
  • DOC for Brucella (doxycycline + rifampicin)
  • Effective against Gram positive bacteria (including MRSA)
  • Effective against Gram negative bacteria (including Pseudomonas)
  • It was used for prophylaxis of meningococcus meningitis

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis.
  • Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase enzyme.
  • Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation
  • Rifampicin inhibit RNA polymerase

choices.text: 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated
90% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in smokers if smoking is eliminated
10% cases of lung cancer can be eliminated in population if smoking is eliminated

questions.text: A 45-year-old researcher is keenly interested in understanding the relationship between lung cancer and smoking habits. After conducting an extensive study and analyzing his data, he finds that the attributable risk is 90%. Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation of this result? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 10% of lung cancers in smokers is not associated with smoking

 

  • In the given scenario, the attributable risk of cigarette smoking to lung cancer is 90%; hence, 90% cases of lung cancer are due to smoking as a risk factor
  • The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed is given by the attributable risk.
  • Attributable risk is the difference in risk of disease between two groups (exposed and non-exposed) and represents the proportion of disease occurrence that can be attributed to the exposure.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Interpretation of AR (attributable risk): AR is indicative of the extent of the disease attributed to the exposure
  • Interpretation of PAR (Population attributable risk): If risk factor is modified or eliminated, there will be so much annual reduction in incidence of disease in the given population

questions.text: All of the following are examples of passive immunity except: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Toxoid

 

Passive immunity refers to the transfer of ready-made antibodies from outside the body to provide immediate but temporary protection against infection. It doesn't involve the immune system actively producing antibodies.

 

Toxoid is an example of active immunity, not passive immunity. Toxoids are bacterial toxins that have been modified to destroy their harmful properties while retaining their ability to stimulate antibody production when introduced into the body. When toxoids are administered (like in tetanus or diphtheria vaccines), they stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies, which is the hallmark of active immunity. Active immunity takes time to develop but provides long-lasting protection.

 

Passive immunity involves preformed immunity from outside that is directly transferred to the body in the form of immunoglobulins or through mother-to-child transmission. Examples include immunoglobulin A (IgA), antitoxins, and monoclonal antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toxoids (like those used in tetanus and diphtheria vaccines) stimulate active immunity rather than providing passive immunity.

questions.text: Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) Program does not include: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) OCD

 

The Mental Health Gap Action Program (mhGAP) by the World Health Organization (WHO) is designed to scale up services for mental, neurological, and substance use disorders, particularly in low- and middle-income countries. The program focuses on priority conditions that are of high burden and can be managed effectively in primary care settings.

 

The mnemonic "MESSI DAD" can be used to remember the disorders included in the mhGAP program:

 

  • M: Mental disorders in children (Option A)
  • E: Epilepsy
  • S: Suicide
  • S: Schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders (Option B)
  • I: Illicit drug use disorders
  • D: Depression (Option D)
  • A: Alcohol-related disorders
  • D: Dementia

 

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) is not included in the list of target conditions under the mhGAP program, which is why it is the correct answer to this question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder) is not included in the WHO's Mental Health Gap Action (mhGAP) program, which focuses on other high-burden mental health conditions.

questions.text: An individual experienced a dog bite. Both the person and the dog are up-to-date with their vaccinations. The person's medical history includes a splenectomy performed five years ago. What is the optimal course of action for managing this situation? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Amoxiclav

 

  • Amoxicillin/clavulanate (Augmentin) is generally considered the first-line prophylactic treatment for animal bites.
  • Appropriate tetanus and rabies prophylaxis as indicated should also be a part of caring for a patient who has sustained a dog bite, as well as local debridement and thorough cleaning of the wound

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation: Observation alone is not sufficient due to the risk of infection, especially in an asplenic individual.

 

Option C. Metronidazole: This antibiotic is not typically used as monotherapy for animal bites as it does not cover the range of bacteria commonly involved.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: While it has some coverage, it is not the first-line treatment for dog bites and lacks the broad coverage provided by amoxicillin/clavulanate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amoxicillin/clavulanate is the optimal course of action for prophylactic treatment following a dog bite, especially in individuals with increased infection risk, such as those with a history of splenectomy.
  • Thorough wound care and appropriate prophylaxis for tetanus and rabies should also be part of the management plan.

questions.text: Which type of graph is used to illustrate studies on healthcare and disease prevalence in a population? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Ishikawa diagram/Fish bone diagram

 

Explanation

 

Ishikawa Diagram/Fish Bone Diagram/ Cause & Effect Diagram:

 

Description: A visual tool that helps trace a problem’s cause back to its roots, creating a branched diagram that looks like a fishbone.

 

Application: Used to identify, explore, and display the possible causes of a particular problem, particularly useful in quality control and prevention strategies in healthcare.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Bar Diagram:

 

Description: Bar diagrams use bars of varying lengths to represent data. Each bar corresponds to a category with a specific quantity.

 

Application: Useful for comparing quantities across different categories, such as the number of cases in different disease categories or patient counts in various demographic groups.

 

Option B. Histogram:

 

Description: A histogram is similar to a bar chart but is used for continuous quantitative data divided into bins or intervals. It helps in understanding the distribution of data.

 

Application: Commonly used to show the distribution of a dataset, such as the age distribution of patients suffering from a specific disease or the distribution of blood pressure readings in a population.

 

Option C. Multiple Regression Model:

 

Description: Not a graph, but a statistical technique that models the relationship between a dependent variable and multiple independent variables.

 

Application: Used to predict outcomes based on several variables, such as predicting patient outcomes based on age, treatment type, and pre-existing conditions.

 

Educational objectives : Fishbone diagrams are instrumental in root cause analysis, helping healthcare teams systematically investigate the contributory factors leading to health issues or outbreaks.

questions.text: Mineral deficiency clinically found to be associated with sexual dysfunction is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Zinc

 

Zinc deficiency is well-documented to be associated with several reproductive and sexual health issues. It is particularly known for causing Acrodermatitis Enteropathica, a rare genetic disorder.

 

Zinc deficiency can lead to sexual infantilism, sterility, diarrhea, brittle nails, loss of taste, growth failure, etc. Additionally, zinc is crucial for maintaining healthy testosterone levels, which is vital for sexual health in both men and women.

 

In pregnancy, zinc deficiency can result in low birth weight, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), congenital malformations, and even spontaneous abortions, further highlighting its critical role in reproductive health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Molybdenum: Molybdenum deficiency is associated with conditions such as mouth or esophageal cancer and respiratory and neurological issues. There is no direct link between molybdenum deficiency and sexual dysfunction.

 

Option B. Copper: Copper deficiency can lead to anemia, bone fractures, neutropenia, osteoporosis, depigmentation of the skin, and thyroid issues. However, it is not linked to sexual dysfunction.

 

Option D. Magnesium: Magnesium deficiency is primarily associated with irritability, tetany, hyperreflexia, and impaired metabolism of potassium and calcium. It does not have a direct connection with sexual dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sexual dysfunction occur due to deficiency of Zinc, calcium, Vitamin D and B12. Essential fatty acid deficiency may also be associated with sexual dysfunction.

questions.text: Based on the depiction in the accompanying image, which model of disease causation is being illustrated? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Sufficient component cause model 

 

  • The model of disease causation depicted is a sufficient component cause model.
  • It was developed by Rothman based on the idea that an outcome can only happen when a sufficient cause is present.
  • A disease can have multiple sufficient causes. But each sufficient cause can consist of a pie chart of component causes, a causal pie.
  • One component cause can be a part of more than one sufficient cause.
  • A component cause can be considered necessary if it is a part of a disease's sufficient causes.
  • In the given model, each pie chart represents a sufficient cause made of component causes.
  • Since B is present in all the charts, it can be considered a necessary cause. All the others are contributing causes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epidemiological triad: An epidemiological triad depicts the interrelationship between the causative agent, the host, and the environment. All of them contribute to disease development. The aim of an epidemiological triad is to identify how to break this relationship and prevent the outbreak of the disease.

 

Option C. PERT model: PERT is used for network analysis. It is a type of quantitative management technique that helps in detailed planning and comprehensive supervision.

 

 

Option D. Web of causation model: The web of causation considers all the predisposing factors and their complex interrelationship with each other. This model is ideally suited to study chronic disease. The web of causation does not imply that the disease is controlled only when all the multiple chains of causation are removed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sufficient component cause model illustrates how multiple factors contribute to disease causation, with some factors being necessary components in multiple causal pathways.

choices.text: Only CD4 contributed to graft rejection significantly
Only CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly
Both CD4 and CD8 protected against graft rejection significantly
Both CD4 and CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly

questions.text: For the given Kaplan-Meier curve on the role of T-cells in the allograft rejection process, true statement is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Both CD4 and CD8 contributed to graft rejection significantly

 

The Kaplan-Meier curve presented in this question shows the survival rates of grafts in mice after they were treated with monoclonal antibodies designed to deplete specific T-cells (CD4 and CD8). The survival curves illustrate how the presence or absence of these T-cells affects graft rejection.

 

  • Anti-CD8 Group (Pink Line): The curve for mice treated with anti-CD8 antibodies (which deplete CD8 T-cells) shows a survival rate very similar to the control group. This indicates that the removal of CD8 T-cells alone does not significantly affect graft survival.
  • Anti-CD4 Group (Blue Line): The curve for the anti-CD4 group shows an extended graft survival compared to the control and anti-CD8 groups. This indicates that CD4 T-cells play a more significant role in graft rejection than CD8 T-cells alone. Removal of CD4 prolongs survival from 15 to 30 days.
  • Anti-CD4 + Anti-CD8 Group (Green Line): The green curve represents mice treated with both anti-CD4 and anti-CD8 antibodies. This group shows the longest survival of grafts, extending up to 60 days. The combination of depleting both CD4 and CD8 T-cells significantly delays graft rejection, demonstrating that both types of T-cells are involved in the rejection process.

 

The conclusion drawn from this curve is that both CD4 and CD8 T-cells contribute to graft rejection, and their combined effect is more pronounced than the effect of either cell type alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both CD4 and CD8 T-cells are crucial contributors to the allograft rejection process, and their combined depletion significantly prolongs graft survival.

choices.text: Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital
Perform more small incision cataract surgery
To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots
To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of progressive vision loss is scheduled for cataract surgery under the National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment. Which of the following is NOT an accurate guideline or inclusion criterion for cataract surgery within this national program? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) To do surgery in rural area with make shift hospital/Ots

 

Explanation:

 

To do surgery in rural area with makeshift hospital/Ots is not advisable, suggests conducting surgeries in temporary setups or less equipped facilities, typically in rural areas. This is considered unsafe and against the guidelines because such environments cannot guarantee the sterility and safety standards required for surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patients requiring cataract surgeries are selected and asked to report to base hospital: This refers to the standard protocol where patients identified as needing cataract surgery are instructed to come to a base or main hospital that is equipped for such procedures. This ensures that surgeries are performed in a controlled, sterile environment with appropriate medical facilities and staff.

 

Option B. Perform more small incision cataract surgery (SICS): This statement encourages the adoption of small incision cataract surgery, which is a modern technique that allows for quicker recovery times and potentially fewer complications than traditional methods. It is particularly advantageous in resource-limited settings because it does not require expensive machinery like phacoemulsification units.

 

Option D. To perform surgeries in fixed facility surgery by shifting patients from rural area: This approach involves transporting patients from rural and remote areas to fixed, well-equipped surgical facilities, typically located in urban or suburban centers. This ensures all patients receive high-quality care in facilities that meet national and international health and safety standards.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The primary aim of these guidelines is to ensure that all surgeries, particularly sensitive ones like cataract surgery, are performed in environments that uphold the highest standards of medical care and patient safety. The emphasis is on using modern surgical techniques and ensuring that all procedures are carried out in well-equipped, permanent medical facilities to minimize risks and enhance recovery outcomes. The standard guideline includes:

 

  1. Village Register (Linelisting of cases)
  2. Screening camps
  3. Transport of cases to Base hospital
  4. Free surgery – fixed facility surgery approach (Reach in approach at base Hospitals preferred over Reach out approach as camp mode)
  5. Follow up of cases (for this camp mode is preferred)

choices.text: NSAIDS are useful to cure the symptoms
Condoms should be used during intercourse and pregnancy should be avoided
Plasmapheresis has a role in management

questions.text: True regarding prevention of Zika virus is? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Condoms should be used during intercourse and pregnancy should be avoided

 

  • The correct statement regarding prevention of Zika virus is that condoms should be used during intercourse and pregnancy should be avoided.
  • Zika virus can be transmitted not only through the bite of Aedes mosquito but also through body fluids, especially sexual fluids. 
  • The virus is known to have teratogenic effects on fetus.
  • If a pregnant woman is infected with Zika virus, it can lead to serious complications like microcephaly, stillbirth, abortion, death of the newborn, encephalitis, and Guillain-Barre syndrome. 
  • Therefore, it is recommended that pregnancy should be avoided for at least three months after Zika virus infection. 
  • Condoms serve as a barrier method to prevent sexual transmission of the virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NSAIDS are useful to cure the symptoms: This is incorrect. NSAIDs are contraindicated in Zika virus management as they increase the chances of hemorrhagic tendency. Acetyl salicylic acid and NSAIDs are not allowed according to the National Center for Disease Control of India guidelines for the management of Zika virus.

 

Option C. A good vaccine is available: This is incorrect. Currently, there is no approved vaccine available for Zika virus. 

 

Option D. Plasmapheresis has a role in management: This is incorrect. Plasmapheresis has a limited role, and that too only in cases of Guillain-Barre syndrome, which is a rare complication of Zika virus infection. It is not a standard management approach for Zika virus disease itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preventive measures for Zika virus infection, including the importance of condom use during intercourse and avoiding pregnancy due to the risk of teratogenic effects on the fetus.

questions.text: Calculate the median from the given set of observations: 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 4, 8. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 4.5


The median is the middle value of a data set when arranged in ascending order. For an even number of observations, the median is found by taking the average of the two middle numbers. In this set, the values in ascending order are: 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8. Since there are 8 values (an even number), the two middle values are 4 and 5. The median is calculated by averaging these two values:

 

Median = (4+5)/2 = 4.5

 

Educational Objective:
 

For an even number of observations, the median is the average of the two middle values when the data set is arranged in ascending order.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a routine check-up. During the social history taking, she mentions that she has started engaging in certain behaviors and rituals that align with her new community after recently moving to a different country. What is the term for this type of behavior acquisition? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Socialization

 

Explanation:

 

  • Learning and try to adapt to new community. This is known as Socialization
  • Socialization is the process by which individuals learn and adopt the norms, values, and behaviors appropriate to their society. 
  • Socialization is key in helping individuals function as members of their society, and it involves learning the language, norms, and rituals of the community.
  • This term directly applies to the scenario described, as the woman is adopting behaviors that align with her new community.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Custom: This term refers to a traditional and widely accepted way of behaving or doing something that is specific to a particular society, place, or time. Customs are the established patterns of behavior that can be objectively verified within a particular social setting

 

Option B. Culture: Is the learned behavior which is socially acquired. Culture is a broader term that includes knowledge, belief systems, art, morals, laws, and any other capabilities and habits acquired by individuals as members of society.

 

Option D. Mores: These are the moral norms, manners, or customs that are considered important for the welfare of a community and are enforced by social disapproval or formal sanctions if violated. Mores are a subset of social norms that include strong moral connotations and are seen as foundational to societal welfare.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

"Socialization" best captures the process the woman is undergoing as she adopts the practices of her new community.

questions.text: You are a nutritionist giving a lecture about milk pasteurization and its quality assurance tests. A curious student inquires about the various tests to validate the efficacy of pasteurization. You begin to list them, but highlight one that is not directly related to the pasteurization process. Which of the following tests does not directly evaluate the efficiency of milk pasteurization? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) lodine test 

 

  • Given tests are associated with the milk pasteurization process except for the iodine test.
  • This test is conducted to examine the potential adulteration of milk with starch or cereal flour.
  • Iodine test - The presence of addition of starch in milk can be detected using an iodine test.
  • When two or three drops of iodine solution is added to milk taken in a test tube, the solution turns dark blue.
  • This shows the presence of starch mixed with the milk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphatase Test: Used to check for the presence of the enzyme phosphatase, which should be inactivated by proper pasteurization. This ensures that the milk has been heated sufficiently.

 

Option C. Standard Plate Count: Measures the total bacterial count to ensure it meets the standards for pasteurized milk. A lower count indicates effective pasteurization.

 

Option D. Methylene Blue Reduction Test: Measures the time it takes for methylene blue to lose its color, which correlates with bacterial activity; high counts indicate inadequate pasteurization. This test helps verify the reduction of microbial load.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PASTEURIZATION TESTS:

 

  1. Phosphatase Test: Widely used test
  2. Standard Plate Count: Standard is coliforms be absent in 1 ml of milk
  3. Methylene blue reduction test: Enforced limit is 30,000 bacterial count per ml of pasteurized milk

questions.text: A clinician is examining various approaches to determine the rate at which a contraceptive method fails. Which index is specifically employed for this purpose? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Pearl index

 

  • Pearl index is the common method used to measure contraceptive failure rate.
  • It is defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY). This rate is given by the formula:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pharmacological index: This term is generally refers to the study and categorization of drugs based on their effects and properties.

 

Option C. Performance index: This may refer to various metrics used to evaluate the performance of processes or systems in different fields.

 

Option D. Efficacy index: While this might be used to measure the effectiveness of a treatment or intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Pearl Index is the standard measure used to determine the contraceptive failure rate, defined as the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure.
  • This index helps in evaluating the reliability and effectiveness of various contraceptive methods

questions.text: Imagine a scenario where a novel medication is introduced that significantly reduces mortality from a specific disease but does not actually cure the disease. As patients continue to live longer with the disease due to this medication, it would have an effect on the epidemiological metrics. Which of the following statements correctly describes the expected change in prevalence and incidence as a result of this medication? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase in prevalence

 

  • The given scenario shows that there is a drug which can reduce mortality but cannot cure a particular disease.
  • So, old cases will live longer and thus, there will be increase in prevalence. Incidence will not get affected due to this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in incidence: Incorrect, as the medication does not affect the rate at which new cases occur.

 

Option B. Decrease in prevalence: Incorrect, since patients living longer with the disease will increase prevalence.

 

Option C. Increase in incidence: Incorrect, because incidence measures new cases, not the duration or survival of existing cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PREVALENCE

 

  • Total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over.
  • Prevalence = Incidence × Mean duration of disease [P = I × d]
  • Prevalence describes the balance between incidence, mortality and recovery

 

INCIDENCE

 

  • Number of new cases occurring in a defined population over a specified period of time.

choices.text: Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and standard of living
Infant mortality rate, literacy and standard of living
Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate

questions.text: You are a global health researcher working on a report assessing the development status of various countries. To classify the countries and compare them, you decide to use the Human Development Index (HDI). You recall that HDI is a commonly utilized measure but seek to clarify its exact components, as presented by organizations like the World Health Organization (WHO). Which of the following correctly identifies the components that make up the HDI? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Life expectancy at birth, literacy and standard of living 

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 

The Human Development Index (HDI) is a composite statistic used to rank countries based on human development levels. It consists of three main components:

 

  • Life Expectancy at Birth: Measures the average number of years a newborn is expected to live.
  • Education (Literacy and Mean Years of Schooling): Assesses the average number of years of education received by people ages 25 and older and the expected years of schooling for children entering school.
  • Standard of Living (Gross National Income per capita): Adjusted for purchasing power parity (PPP).

 

Note -

 

  • HDI values range: 0 to + 1
  • HDI India is 0. 633 (Rank 134 out of 186 countries)
  • Human poverty index [HPI] is complementary to HDI

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a study involving radiographic evaluations, two physicians independently assessed 100 chest X-rays. They calculated a Kappa statistic of 0.71 to measure inter-rater agreement. What does this Kappa value indicate about the level of agreement between the two doctors? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Substantial

 

Explanation:

 

The Kappa statistic is used to measure the degree of agreement between two raters beyond what would be expected by chance. Here's what each value typically indicates about the level of agreement:

 

A. Slight: A Kappa value from 0.01 to 0.20. This range indicates that there is minimal agreement between the two raters, barely above what would be expected by random chance.

 

B. Fair: A Kappa value from 0.21 to 0.40. This suggests there is some agreement between the raters, but it remains relatively low.

 

C. Moderate: A Kappa value from 0.41 to 0.60. This level indicates a moderate amount of agreement, showing that the raters often agree on their assessments.

 

D. Substantial: A Kappa value from 0.61 to 0.80. This indicates a high level of agreement, suggesting that the raters consistently agree in their assessments most of the time.

 

E. Near Perfect agreement – kappa value from 0.81 to 0.99

 

F. Perfect agreement – Kappa value – 1.00

 

In this  case, a Kappa value of 0.71 falls within the "Substantial" category, indicating a strong and consistent level of agreement between the two physicians assessing the chest X-rays. This is generally considered an excellent result in clinical settings, as it shows that both observers have a similar interpretation of the radiographic images, which can greatly improve diagnostic accuracy and patient care.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • The Kappa statistic is a reliable tool for assessing the consistency and reliability of diagnostic interpretations between different raters, especially in medical imaging where subjective judgment can vary.
  • High Kappa values, like 0.71, reinforce the reliability of the assessments and the potential for standardized approaches in clinical practice

questions.text: Sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipette is: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Autoclaving and 70% ethanol

 

The most effective sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipettes, as indicated by the available methods, is autoclaving in combination with 70% ethanol.

 

Autoclaving is a reliable method of sterilization that involves exposing the material to high temperature and pressure (121°C at 15 psi) for a specific period, typically 20 minutes. This method effectively kills bacteria, viruses, and spores.

 

Chemical disinfectants

 

 

So, 70% ethanol is widely used as a disinfectant due to its ability to denature proteins and dissolve lipids, making it highly effective at eliminating microbial contamination on glass surfaces.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microwaving and 95% ethanol: Microwaving is not a standard sterilization method for glass pipettes. Although 95% ethanol can be used for disinfection, it is less effective than 70% ethanol because it evaporates too quickly to kill all microbes thoroughly.

 

Option B. Autoclaving: While autoclaving alone is an effective sterilization method, the question specifies the tip of disposable glass pipettes, where combining it with 70% ethanol enhances the sterilization process.

 

Option D. Hot air oven: A hot air oven can be used for sterilization, but it requires longer exposure times at higher temperatures. This method is less efficient compared to autoclaving combined with ethanol, especially for small, delicate items like pipette tips.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective sterilization technique for the tip of disposable glass pipettes is autoclaving combined with 70% ethanol. Autoclaving provides high heat and pressure to eliminate microorganisms, while 70% ethanol ensures thorough disinfection.

questions.text: For which medical condition is the provided drug typically recommended? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Malaria

 

The picture depicts artemisin-based combination therapy (ACT). This medicine is used to treat falciparum malaria.

 

ARTEMISINS - Artesunate and Artemether

 

  • Fastest acting anti-malarial
  • Effective against MDR parasites
  • Short acting
  • C/I in 1st trimester

 

Artemisin Combination Therapy [ACT]

 

  • Artemisin + Long acting drug
  • DOC for chloroquine resistant malaria Combinations
  • Artemether + Lumefantrine: DOC in North Eastern States
  • Artesunate + Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine: DOC for rest of India
  • The dose of artesunate is 200 mg OD for 3 days whereas sulfadoxine (1500 mg) and pyrimethamine (75 mg) should be taken on day 1 only

 

Educational Objective:

 

Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT), is typically recommended for the treatment of falciparum malaria.

choices.text: Not given after 6 months of age
Given as monovalent and pentavalent vaccine

questions.text: All are true about Rotaviral vaccine except: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Not given after 6 months of age

 

The Rotaviral vaccine is included in the National Immunization Schedule of India and is primarily available in two types: Rotavac and Rotasil.
 

 

Note -

 

  • The vaccine is typically given at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of age under NIS, with the possibility of extending the schedule up to 12 months in cases of delayed immunization.
  • Both vaccines are live attenuated, but VP8 subunit vaccine is also available, offering more strain specificity and showing good results in infants, adolescents, and adults.

 

However, it is incorrect to state that the vaccine is "Not given after 6 months of age," as it can be administered up to 12 months of age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subunit vaccine: This statement is true as there is a subunit vaccine for rotavirus, specifically the VP8 subunit V protein vaccine, which has shown good results in various age groups.

 

Option C. Oral route of administration: This is correct. Rotaviral vaccines are given orally.

 

Option D. Given as monovalent and pentavalent vaccine: This is also correct. Rotavac is a monovalent vaccine, and Rotasil is a pentavalent vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Rotaviral vaccine can be given up to 12 months of age according to the National Immunization Schedule of India.

choices.text: Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, skewed with outliers
Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers
Normal, negatively skewed, positively skewed, normal with outliers
Skewed with outliers, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal

questions.text: What information is conveyed by the graph presented below? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Normal, positively skewed, negatively skewed, normal with outliers 

 

The given Box and Whisker plot depicts different types of data distributions:

 

  1. Normal distribution - The median is in the middle of the box, with whiskers of equal length.
  2. Positively skewed distribution - The median is closer to the bottom of the box, with a longer whisker on the upper end.
  3. Negatively skewed distribution - The median is closer to the top of the box, with a longer whisker on the lower end.
  4. Normal distribution with outliers - The median is in the middle of the box, with equal whisker lengths and the presence of outliers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Box and Whisker plot

 

  • A graphical presentation of Numerical Data through its quartiles.
  • It has a box in the center and two wishers in its sides.
  • The box has got 2 ends, Quartile 1 (Q1) & Quartile 3 (Q3)
  • The vertical line inside the box is called median also known as Q2. The whole data is divided into 4 Quartiles
  • The lower end of one whisker represent the minimum value of the distribution.
  • The higher end of other Whisker represents the maximum value of the distribution.

questions.text: Definitive Investigation for a patient of dengue who presented with features of Dengue hemorrhagic syndrome since last 5 days is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) RT-PCR

 

RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction) is the most definitive investigation for diagnosing dengue, particularly in the first five days of illness. RT-PCR is highly sensitive and specific, capable of detecting the viral RNA present in the blood.

 

Although NS1 antigen detection is another option for early diagnosis, RT-PCR provides more reliable results, especially around the 3rd day of illness.

 

Studies indicate that within the first five days, RT-PCR is superior to the NS1 antigen test in detecting dengue infection. After five days, when the viral RNA levels decrease, ELISA IgM becomes a more suitable test as it detects the presence of antibodies developed against the virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NS-1 antigen: The NS1 antigen test is useful in the early diagnosis of dengue, typically within the first few days of illness. However, it is most effective around the 2nd day of illness and is less reliable compared to RT-PCR by the 5th day.

 

Option C. Viral culture: Viral culture is not typically used in clinical settings for the diagnosis of dengue because it is time-consuming, requires specialized facilities, and is less practical for rapid diagnosis.

 

Option D. ELISA IgM: ELISA IgM is a serological test that detects antibodies produced in response to dengue infection. It becomes more effective after 5 days of illness, when the immune response is more developed, making it unsuitable for diagnosis within the first five days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with dengue symptoms within the first five days, RT-PCR is the definitive diagnostic test due to its high sensitivity and ability to detect viral RNA during this critical period.

questions.text: WMA’s Declaration of Oslo is related to: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Therapeutic abortion

 

The World Medical Association's (WMA) Declaration of Oslo is specifically related to the ethical considerations surrounding therapeutic abortion. This declaration emphasizes that medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) should be conducted under specific conditions to ensure it is ethical and safe.

 

The key focus areas of the Oslo Declaration include:

 

MTP must be done only due to:

 

  1. Health Reasons: Therapeutic abortion should only be performed when it is medically necessary for the health of the patient. This may include physical, mental, or social reasons that could adversely affect the well-being of the patient.
  2. Informed Consent: Both the patient and the healthcare provider must fully understand and agree to the procedure. It is essential that both parties are convinced of the necessity and appropriateness of the abortion.
  3. Legal Compliance: The procedure must comply with the local laws governing abortion in the specific region, territory, or country. Legal regulations vary, and it is crucial to adhere to them.
  4. Competent Personnel: The procedure should be carried out by competent surgeons. If the situation allows, trained professional health workers who are competent and authorized by law can also perform the procedure.

 

These principles ensure that therapeutic abortions are conducted in a manner that prioritizes the safety, rights, and well-being of the patient while adhering to ethical and legal standards.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hunger: The Declaration of Oslo is not related to hunger. Hunger and food security issues are addressed by different international organizations and declarations, but not by this specific WMA declaration.

 

Option B. State of prisoners: The Oslo Declaration does not deal with the treatment or state of prisoners. Other international conventions, like the Geneva Conventions, cover the rights and treatment of prisoners.

 

Option C. Ethics in Medical Research: Although the WMA has issued other declarations related to ethics in medical research, such as the Declaration of Helsinki, Nuremberg code and Belmont report.

 

Additional Information

 

Declaration of Geneva: related to the physician's dedication to humanitarian goals of medicine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WMA’s Declaration of Oslo is specifically related to the ethical guidelines surrounding therapeutic abortion, emphasizing health reasons, informed consent, legal compliance, and the requirement for competent medical personnel.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to your clinic with a concern about a hypopigmented patch on her forearm. She has noticed reduced sensation over the patch. During the physical examination, you also notice thickening of some peripheral nerves. Which of the following combinations of criteria would be appropriate for diagnosing Leprosy in suspected cases? [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. Hypopigmented skin lesions with sensory deficit
  2. Peripheral nerve thickening with sensory loss and muscle weakening
  3. Family history of leprosy
  4. Slit skin smears
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

To diagnose Leprosy, at least one of the following cardinal signs must be present:

 

1. Hypopigmented or reddish skin lesions with definite sensory deficit: This is a primary indicator of Leprosy. The presence of sensory deficits in these lesions points to the nerve involvement characteristic of the disease.

 

2. Peripheral nerve involvement - thickening with sensory loss and muscle weakening/paralysis: Thickening of peripheral nerves, combined with sensory loss and muscle weakening or paralysis, is another key indicator of Leprosy. These clinical signs suggest the spread of the infection to peripheral nerves.

 

4. Demonstration of M. leprae in lesions (Slit skin smears): This involves laboratory confirmation through slit skin smears showing the presence of Mycobacterium leprae. It is a definitive diagnostic method for Leprosy.

 

Other Options:

 

3. family history of leprosy is not considered one of the cardinal signs necessary for diagnosis. It is more relevant in understanding the epidemiological context rather than serving as a primary diagnostic criterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At least one of the following cardinal signs must be present to diagnose Leprosy

 

  1. Hypopigmented or reddish skin lesions with definite sensory deficit
  2. Peripheral nerve involvement - thickening with sensory loss and muscle weakening/paralysis
  3. Demonstration of M. leprae in lesions (Slit skin smears)

choices.text: Give DMPA with 7 days of barrier

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with no significant medical history, who has been using depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) for contraception, presents to the clinic after missing her scheduled injection by 14 days. She denies any sexual activity since her last injection. Her last menstrual period was 10 weeks ago, and she has no signs of pregnancy. What is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient regarding contraception? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Give DMPA

 

Explanation:

 

  • As per the ministry of health and family welfare guidelines, ideally Inj DMPA (Antara) should be administered 3 monthly as shown in the table below:

 

Follow up of clients (coming on scheduled date for next injection i.e after 3 months

 

 

  • Defaulter: A defaulter is a client who does not return for the next injection on the scheduled date; but comes for it within the grace period i.e. 2 weeks earlier and upto 4 weeks later from the scheduled date).

 

 

Drop out: A dropout is a MPAclient who comes for the next injection after the grace period of 4 weeks is over and more than 4 months have passed since she took her last injection

 

 

In the scenario mentioned above, the patient is a DEFAULTER and hence the Inj should be administered as she falls within the grace period

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. UPT before DMPA: This would be appropriate if the patient was a drop-out, i.e. if she had presented > 4 weeks of the date that she had to come on. 

 

Option C. Give DMPA with 7 days of barrier: This approach would be recommended if the injection was delayed beyond 4 weeks. 

 

Option D. Wait till next period: This unnecessarily delays contraceptive protection and is not recommended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient misses her scheduled DMPA injection by up to 30 days, the most appropriate recommendation is to administer DMPA directly without pregnancy testing. 

  • This is because Inj DMPA is known to cause a delayed return to fertlity. 

  • This ensures continuous contraceptive protection while following evidence-based guidelines that balance safety with practical clinical considerations.

questions.text: During a global health conference, you're in a discussion with fellow epidemiologists about the changing patterns of disease occurrence over the years. The conversation shifts towards the steady rise in non-communicable diseases over a considerable time span. One of your colleagues quizzes the group on the terminology for such a trend. Which term best describes this pattern of increasing prevalence over extended periods? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Secular 

 

  • This kind of pattern can be explained by secular trend.
  • Secular Trends (Long Term Fluctuations): Implies changes in occurrence of a disease (progressive increase or decrease) over a long period of time, generally several years or decades.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seasonal: Seasonal trends (Periodic fluctuations) is seasonal variation/fluctuation in occurrence of a disease. Examples: Measles (early spring), upper respiratory infection (winters), gastrointestinal infection (summer).

 

Option B. Cyclical: Cyclic trend (Periodic fluctuations) is occurrence of a disease in cycles spread over short periods of time, which may be days, weeks, months or years. Examples: Measles (every 2-3 years), Rubella (every 6-9 years), Influenza pandemics (every 10-15 years).

 

Option C. Periodic: Periodic fluctuations include both Seasonal and cyclical trends.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secular trends describe long-term changes in disease occurrence over years or decades, distinct from seasonal or cyclical variations.

questions.text: You're mentoring a group of budding epidemiologists who are keen on understanding the nuances of different study designs. One of them is particularly interested in case-control studies. During your discussion, you decide to quiz them on aspects that are typically not inherent to case-control studies. Which of the given options would not usually be part of a case-control study? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Follow up 

 

  • Follow up is not a component of case-control studies.
  • These studies are retrospective and do not involve tracking subjects over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Matching: Process of selecting controls in a such a way that they are similar to cases (with regard to certain pertinent selected variables which may influence the outcome of disease, thereby distorting the results). It eliminates confounding.

 

Option C. Strength of association: In case-control studies, the strength of association is measured using the odds ratio (an estimate of relative risk).

 

Option D. Selection of study subjects: Essential in case-control studies, involving the selection of cases with the disease and controls without the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Case-control studies do not include follow-up of subjects but focus on matching, assessing the strength of association using odds ratios, and selecting cases and controls for analysis.

choices.text: To improve quality of life patient
Nothing is done in palliative care

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of stage IV non-small cell lung cancer presents with worsening dyspnea, non-productive cough, and uncontrolled pain despite current medication. He has declined further aggressive treatment. What stands true for Palliative care? [INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) To improve quality of life patient

 

Explanation:

 

  • Palliative care is a specialized medical care focused on providing relief from the symptoms and stress of a serious illness.
  • The primary goal of palliative care is to improve the quality of life for the patient. 
  • It involves treating pain and other distressing symptoms, providing psychological and spiritual care, and supporting the patient and their family to cope with the challenges of a serious illness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To cure disease: This is incorrect. Palliative care does not aim to cure the underlying disease but focuses on alleviating symptoms and improving the quality of life for both the patient and their family.

 

Option B. Do nothing to prolong life: Palliative care does not necessarily aim to prolong life, nor does it hasten death. It’s about enhancing the quality of life and may also indirectly prolong it by improving general health and well-being.

 

Option D. Nothing is done in palliative care: This is incorrect. Palliative care involves active and comprehensive management of various issues that arise with serious illnesses, including physical, emotional, social, and spiritual aspects of care.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Palliative care is crucial for improving the quality of life for patients with serious illnesses. 
  • It addresses a wide range of needs, ensuring the patient’s comfort and supporting the family through difficult times, emphasizing symptom management and personal support over curative treatments.

questions.text: Reliable feature of some dehydration is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Thirst

 

Thirst is recognized as the most reliable feature of some dehydration. When dehydration begins to set in, the body's initial response is to signal thirst as a way to encourage fluid intake. This response is consistent across various cases of mild to moderate dehydration. Unlike other symptoms, thirst is a direct and early indicator of dehydration that can be easily recognized by the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delayed skin pinch: Skin turgor, or the delayed return of the skin to its normal position after being pinched, is influenced by several factors, including nutritional status. This makes it less reliable as a sole indicator of dehydration.

 

Option B. Lethargy: Lethargy can be a symptom of dehydration, but it is difficult to quantify and may vary widely depending on the individual's overall health and the severity of dehydration.

 

Option D. Sunken eyes: The appearance of sunken eyes is quite subjective and often requires the input of a caregiver, such as a parent, to determine whether it is present. It is also not always a definitive sign of dehydration, making it less reliable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thirst is the most reliable and early feature of some dehydration, making it a critical symptom to recognize in assessing dehydration

questions.text: In a village population, patients having diabetes and hypertension are enumerated. Then their family members are screening for diabetes and hypertension. This is a type of: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Selective screening

 

  • This is an example of selective screening, which is a type of screening applied to high-risk groups - individuals who have a higher chance of developing a particular disease. 
  • In this case, family members of patients with diabetes and hypertension are being screened because they are at higher risk of developing these conditions due to genetic predisposition and shared environmental factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mass screening: This is incorrect because mass screening refers to screening applied to a large population without considering risk factors. Mass screening is conducted on a "large number of people" without specific risk targeting, like "chest x-ray in elderly for lung cancer." The given scenario is specifically targeting family members of already diagnosed patients, not the entire population.

 

Option C. Multiphasic screening: This is incorrect because multiphasic screening involves applying more than two tests to a large number of people. Multiphasic screening as where "more than 2 tests are used or applied in large number of people like annual health checkup." In the given scenario, we're only screening for two specific conditions (diabetes and hypertension) in a targeted group, not conducting multiple tests on a large population.

 

Option D. Anonymous screening: This is incorrect because refers to a type of medical testing where individuals are tested for a condition (such as HIV) without providing any personal identifying information. 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In Demographic cycle, B curve represents: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Death rate

 

In the demographic cycle, the B curve represents the death rate (Crude Death Rate - CDR). The demographic cycle is divided into five stages, which are primarily determined by birth and death rates:

 

  1. Stage 1 (High Stationary): Both the birth rate (A) and the death rate (B) are high, resulting in a stable population.
  2. Stage 2 (Early Expanding): The birth rate (A) remains high while the death rate (B) starts to decline due to improved medical facilities, causing the population to increase.
  3. Stage 3 (Late Expanding): Both birth and death rates start declining, often due to the introduction of family planning and other socio-economic factors. India is currently in this stage.
  4. Stage 4 (Low Stationary): Both rates decline to a low level, stabilizing the population growth.
  5. Stage 5 (Declining): The birth rate drops below the death rate, leading to a reduction in population size.

 

In this context, Curve B clearly represents the death rate as it follows the pattern of decline in stages 2 and 3, stabilizes in stage 4, and may increase slightly in stage 5.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Birth rate: Incorrect. Curve A represents the birth rate (Crude Birth Rate - CBR), which remains high initially but starts to decline from stage 3 onwards.

 

Option C. Growth rate: Incorrect. Growth rate is not directly shown on the graph; it is inferred from the difference between birth and death rates.

 

Option D. Total population: Incorrect. Curve C represents the total population, which increases as the death rate declines and stabilizes when both rates are low.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The B curve in the demographic cycle represents the death rate, which declines significantly from stage 2 due to improved healthcare and stabilizes in later stages.

questions.text: All of the following are the components of Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme except: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 6 health functionaries

 

  • Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) or Intensified Iron Plus Initiative launched in 2018 uses a strategic framework called the 6x6x6 strategy. 
  • This includes 6 beneficiaries, 6 interventions, and 6 institutional mechanisms. 
  • The program does not include "6 health functionaries" as a component.

 

The 6x6x6 strategy includes:

 

1. 6 beneficiaries:

 

  • Children aged 6-59 months
  • Children aged 5-9 years
  • Adolescents aged 10-19 years
  • Women of reproductive age (20-49 years, non-pregnant, non-lactating)
  • Pregnant women
  • Lactating women

 

2. 6 interventions:

 

  • Iron and folic acid supplementation
  • Deworming (biannually with albendazole)
  • Behavior change communication
  • Iron fortified foods
  • Testing and treatment of anemia
  • Increasing awareness about non-nutritional causes of anemia

 

3. 6 institutional mechanisms for program implementation and monitoring

 

  • The main aim of the Anemia Mukt Bharat program is to reduce the prevalence of anemia by 3 percentage points per year among children, adolescents, and women in the reproductive age group (15-49 years) between 2018-2022.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Anemia Mukt Bharat program follows a 6x6x6 strategy which includes 6 beneficiaries, 6 interventions, and 6 institutional mechanisms, but does not include 6 health functionaries.

 

 

IFA TABLETS [Anemia Mukt Bharat]

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented to OPD of a PHC Watery diarrhea having severe dehydration. Most likely causative agent underlying would be: [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Rota virus

 

  • Rotavirus is the most common cause of severe diarrhea among young children, especially those under 5 years of age. 
  • Rotavirus primarily affects the small intestine, causing malabsorption and secretory diarrhea, which can lead to rapid dehydration. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shigella: Incorrect. Shigella invades the colonic mucosa, causing inflammation and ulceration, which results in the characteristic bloody stools with mucus. It is not the most common cause of watery diarrhea with severe dehydration in young children.

 

Option B. E.Coli O157:H7: Incorrect. E. coli O157:H7 is an enterohemorrhagic strain that primarily causes bloody diarrhea, not watery diarrhea.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Incorrect. Salmonella typically causes gastroenteritis with diarrhea, fever, vomiting and is usually accompanied by abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotavirus is the most common cause of watery diarrhea with severe dehydration in young children under 5 years of age.

questions.text: All of the following are types of polysaccharide vaccines except: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Hepatitis B

 

Hepatitis B is not a polysaccharide vaccine. It is a recombinant type of subunit vaccine, which means it is made using genetic engineering techniques to produce the surface antigens of the Hepatitis B virus

 

Other Options:

 

Polysaccharide vaccines are designed to elicit an immune response specifically against the polysaccharides found on the surface of certain bacterial capsules. These vaccines include:

 

Option A. Haemophilus influenzae B (Hib) vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Option B. Pneumococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

 

Option D. Meningococcal vaccine: Targets the polysaccharides on the surface of Neisseria meningitidis.

 

These vaccines may also be available as glycoconjugate vaccines, which are designed to improve immunogenicity, especially in younger populations. However, the vaccine for Salmonella Typhimurium (Typhim VI) is available only in a polysaccharide form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B is a recombinant subunit vaccine, not a polysaccharide vaccine. Polysaccharide vaccines include those for pneumococcus, meningococcus, and Haemophilus influenzae type B.

 

Note - Polysaccharide vaccines work by stimulating the immune system to produce antibodies specifically against the polysaccharide components of the bacterial capsule. These polysaccharides are unique to particular strains or serotypes of bacteria, making the vaccine effective in targeting those specific types.

 

Limitations of Polysaccharide vaccines: serotype-specific and do not facilitate herd immunity due to their lack of a robust T-cell response.

questions.text: Imagine you are a clinician administering vaccines to a group of travelers going to a region with high Hepatitis B prevalence. One of the travelers, who has a background in biology, curiously asks which specific part of the Hepatitis B virus is actually present in the vaccine to induce an immune response. Out of the given options, which antigen is included in the Hepatitis B subunit vaccine? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) HbsAg

 

  • Hepatitis B is endemic throughout the world
  • Hepatitis B subunit vaccines consist of HBsAg (Hepatitis B virus surface antigen).
  • These vaccines are created using large molecules obtained from the immunogenic parts of pathogens through recombinant DNA technology.
  • They contrast with fully inactivated whole-cell vaccines as they exclusively contain the antigenic elements of the pathogen.
  • These elements are essential for prompting a defensive immune reaction.

 

Vaccines for Hepatitis B:

 

  • Plasma derived vaccine:
    • Is formalin inactivated sub-unit vaccine
    • Is based on HBsAg
    • Derived from carriers of Hepatitis B
    • Hepatitis B vaccine, dose schedule in adult (months) 0, 1, 6 months
  • rDNA yeast derived vaccine: Recombinant DNA vaccine (genetically engineered)

 

Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin: 

 

  • Required for immediate protection:
    • Surgeons, nurse, laboratory workers
    • Newborn infants of carrier mothers
    • Sexual contacts of acute Hepatitis B patients
    • Ideally administered within 6 hours (not later than 48 hours)

  • Dose: 0.05–0.07 mL/kg, 2 doses 30 days apart

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hepatitis B subunit vaccine contains HBsAg, which is essential for inducing an immune response against the virus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a rash after a trip. You observe a vector on his skin. Considering common vector-borne diseases, what is the disease transmitted by the vector shown in the image. ([INICET NOV 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Scrub typhus

 

Explanation:

 

The image provided shows a trombiculid mite, which is commonly involved in the transmission of Scrub Typhus.

 

  • Scrub Typhus is caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi and is primarily transmitted through bites of infected chiggers. The disease is prevalent in the Asia-Pacific region, so exposure in those areas following a rash and the sighting of a trombiculid mite on the skin strongly points to Scrub Typhus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Babesiosis: This is transmitted by Ixodes ticks (deer ticks), affecting red blood cells similar to malaria. It is not related to trombiculid mites.

 

Option B. Anaplasmosis: Transmitted by deer ticks and the western black-legged tick, this disease targets white blood cells. It's also not transmitted by trombiculid mites.

 

Option D. Ehrlichiosis: This disease is transmitted by ticks like the lone star tick and affects white blood cells. It does not involve trombiculid mites.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Scrub Typhus is transmitted by trombiculid mites, specifically the chigger larvae. It is characterized by fever, rash, and a black eschar at the site of the mite bite.

 

DOC – Doxycycline (monotherapy)

 

If severe manifestations – Doxycycline + Azithromycin

questions.text: Best test for the diagnosis of disease malaria species is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used for uncomplicated malaria? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Artemether
